title: I want an explanation for this loss
body:
Ahead early game; lose one teamfight about 15 minutes in (if memory serves). We fall behind a little bit but are still strong. They are able to control the entire map with ease after this fight, however, even though we eventually get the only baron of the game. While we have baron, we have no one split pushing, even though we have an Irelia. I decide to do it, I get collapsed on, die and we have no gained map control. After our upteenth skirmish against them (with no map control gained), after baron was gone, they end the game in a very anticlimactic manner. I tried asking my team why we lost, but the only "answer" I got was: don't do what your role can't do. That was said in regards to my attempted splitting when literally no one else on my team would do it, as well as initiating, which, again, my team refused to do regardless of the enemy's mis-positioning.

If no one on my team split pushes, and if I do I die, we lose. If no one on my team initiates and if I do I die, we lose. I can't do everyone's role for them, so what could I do in the future in a similar situation?

For the record, I was ahead in damage most of the game and fully capable of carrying if my team tried.

http://matchhistory.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/#match-details/NA1/2447155277/226900712?tab=overview

replies.body:
Hmm best I can tell, your nexus exploded first.

Also, not every match is winnable. Take the losses and move on.

That passive-defeatist logic is why I can't leave bronze. "Just accept losses" is fucking worthless to tell me. I accepted the loss, I don't accept not understanding why. I also don't understand why you added nothing with such an irrelevant response. Are you just trying to be funny, or do you think that: "not every match is winnable. Take the losses and move on" is genuinely good advice?

Come on now; use that brain of yours and help me out here. There was some reason it happened, and I want to be able to deal with it in the future.

No, really. Some losses aren't winnable and there isn't much you can do about it. It's a team game and if your team isn't in sync as much as the enemy team you lose. That's reality, and it isnt defeatist(you aren't playing to lose afterall) but it's not why you can't get out of bronze. Spamming matches averages out the shitters on teams so they are a statistical nonfactor for long term rank gain.

But if you want my quick opinion, your team comp blows goats. They have the better team fight, picks, and map control, with global ults, Cow, and a solid split pusher in Yorick. 

I'd have dodged that match personally, especially with Yasuo on my team with nobody to trigger his ult for him. He's a shitter champ to start with; even worse in bronze in matches they have to rely on their own skill to ult. 

P.S. You could have fixed that comp with an AP JG with CC/Knockup. Then you guys would have at least had a path to victory through team fighting.

>It's a team game and if your team isn't in sync as much as the enemy team you lose.

By that logic, I can only win if I'm lucky. My ability doesn't matter, and whether or not I win isn't dictated by my actions. I just have to hope my team decides to make a collective intelligent decision. 

>That's reality, and it isnt defeatist(you aren't playing to lose afterall) but it's not why you can't get out of bronze.

Oh really? Why can't I leave bronze, then? I've played this game for about 3 years now (with a 10 month hiatus at one point). Is the other team always "in better sync" than my team and able to win because of it? That sounds like nonsense. Also, when I said defeatist, I mean it like this: "I am going to lose and no matter what I do will result in us losing." I didn't mean it like I was playing to lose, it's a philosophical ideology that follows what you are saying to the letter. You are telling me that some games _can't_ be won, regardless of what I do. That is literally defeatism.

>But if you want my quick opinion, your team comp blows goats. They have the better team fight, picks, and map control, with global ults, Cow, and a solid split pusher in Yorick. 

You could have spared the wall of text and just said: "This game was unwinnable from the start, regardless of you or your team's skill.

>P.S. You could have fixed that comp with an AP JG with CC/Knockup. Then you guys would have at least had a path to victory through team fighting.

This is a new account; I literally won't have anyone useful to play for another 500 games. I fucking hate that I am at a disadvantage pick-wise, but I can't do anything about it. Anyways, I felt like our pick potential was very strong, and its strength showed. However, that's meaningless when you are unable to seize any map control. I was just trying something out and lost the game for reasons I can't understand.

No, it doesn't lead to you only winning when lucky. You are part of the team and thus contribute to how well your team is in sync. It's like poker where yeah, luck plays a role, but there is also skill involved in reading other players, reading the cards, and deciding whether to fold and stay in. It also isn't defeatism, it's pragmatism. You don't expect to lose, you don't play to lose. And you always try your best. If you can't separate indicators of loss from your performance, that's on you.   

In tactics/strategy, you push where you have advantage and pull back where you are weak. That isn't defeatism, it's just strategy. Perhaps the confusion comes from you viewing it on an individual match basis while I'm looking at it from the perspective of climbing as a whole. In my mind, individual matches aren't as important as the overall trend.

If you cant leave bronze, it's just because either you aren't playing enough matches, you aren't quite skilled enough at the game to push a team to victory, or some combination. Remember, while I assume you have gotten better over the years, so has the playerbase. To climb you have to get better faster than the playerbase. Roughly half of people are in bronze and always will be, that's how an elo system works. 

As for pick limitations, eh that sucks but it's just another limiter than you gotta work around for now. It'll eventually fix itself.

Thanks for trying to help this person. It's clear though that they don't want to move out of bronze. They ask a million questions, then argue with everyone on all the answers. 

OP isn't looking for answers, just an argument.

>No, it doesn't lead to you only winning when lucky. You are part of the team and thus contribute to how well your team is in sync. 

That's impossible without ample parts communication and individual skill. However, that doesn't matter if my actions and, therefore, skill, are dictated by my teammates. My individual skill doesn't mean anything if my team isn't "in sync." I'm still not seeing how it isn't luck based.

>Perhaps the confusion comes from you viewing it on an individual match basis while I'm looking at it from the perspective of climbing as a whole. In my mind, individual matches aren't as important as the overall trend.

The "overall trend" is winning 38 percent of the games I play, with the number decreasing rapidly (on my other account). I can't climb with that number, obviously. The other "trend" is that this happens most every game. If every game I have lost is like this one, was there no way of changing the outcome?

>If you cant leave bronze, it's just because either you aren't playing enough matches

Several accounts over 3 years; can't leave bronze. I can say with _absolute_ certainty that I have played "enough" games. 

>you aren't quite skilled enough at the game to push a team to victory

But I can only win if my team is "in sync" enough to win! You are telling me that my team _has_ to cooperate, but you are also telling me that I can be "not skilled enough." Which is it? I can't win if I'm not skilled enough, but I can also not win if I am "skilled enough" but my team isn't synchronized? You realize I can just say: "I can't get out of bronze because my teammates are never cooperating," and be _completely_ correct, right?

>To climb you have to get better faster than the playerbase.

You just keep contradicting yourself! Does individual skill matter now? Does it not matter if my team isn't cooperating now? Carrying is possible now? I thought my team _had_ to be in better sync than the other team, apparently, that doesn't mean anything anymore. I can win by simply "being good" now.

I'm trying to follow you here. I don't know if you are trying to tell me that I need to be an initiator and set up plays, or wait for my team to set up plays. I don't get what you mean by "skilled enough," given your point on a team being "synced."

Hmm, I think you are taking it to an extreme. It's not that your team has to be perfectly in sync, it's that they have to be more in sync than the enemy team. That's where your individual skill comes into play. Can you read your own team and enemy teams actions well enough to make decisions? That is one part of skill. Can you then put those decisions into action? That's another part of skill.

Here's an example of being more in sync than the enemy on a small scale that is directly owned by you. Let's say your top laner is hurt and is going to get health plant. Enemy jg happens to be on scuttle and sees your top laner as an easy kill. You are nearby and collapse on enemy jg to help your top laner while enemy top laner does not, and you kill enemy jg without losing your top laner. That secures a small gold advantage. 

In that example, you personally put your team in sync better than the enemy team, at least for that small time period. That's how your individual skill comes into play to influence matches.  

Even if your team isn't acting together, you can try to take opportunities to help them succeed so you can win. Sometimes your team will do the same for you so you can win. Sometimes you can't do it better than the enemy team and you lose. 

Anyway, that's how your team being in sync and personal skill both coexist to determine a games outcome. It isn't just about the others on the team, you are part of the team too and thus make a part of that cohesiveness. By the same token, you are only a part, so even if you have a rock solid game, you won't always get victory. Your participation though is what tilts the odds in your favor. 

If you lose more than you win, the problem is in your own play. It may not be your mechanical skill. It might be your decision making, flexibility, or team play that are the culprit. Can't say without spectating.

I also can't say what you should do, like be an initiator vs be a split pusher etc. That's something that is context sensitive and varies by game. It's part of your decision making skill to learn to tell which option is the best for your situation.

We all have limits to what we can achieve though. For example, in counterstrike, I'll never be top tier because my twitch reaction skills/precision just aren't that great. As league gets progressively twitchier I find myself dropping as well. Just the way it is.

It's possible you just aren't ment to be a good league player for whatever reason.

I see every single game as winnable until my nexus goes down. And it has made me comeback from a dozen or so terrible games, my advice for the future, is to simply be nice and conversational, and try to stay motivational, ive had games wheres its 15-3 and we win and games where its 36-13, all it takes is killing the right person, or magically getting that ace.

I was being "nice and conversational." I even asked my teammate to do something "politely." They didn't exactly listen, but the issue was resolved nonetheless in a few minutes. We lost not because we "lacked motivation;" no, we lost because my teammates were confident that we would win no matter what happened because we dominated early game. Me not being able to split push or initiate or assassinate someone in an instant means we lose because my team didn't do anything to gain map pressure. The game was over _well _ before the nexus was destroyed.

Why was this downvoted?

Cause it's gameplay and everyone downvotes everything in here. Just ignore it and move on.

I mean literally there are people who just go into threads in gameplay and downvote everything lol.
That is why we have the Memes board.

Foxdrop said it best on YouTube:

"In Solo Queue it's better to make the play that your team is committed to than the one that seems the smartest." 

This is because in your typical game of League, not everyone thinks a like and not everyone knows how to play the strategy game. If you're the only one that is thinking about making a specific play but you know you can't do it alone or that you aren't the right member of the team to make that play then it will fail 100% of the time even if it's the best possible play to make. 

HOWEVER

If you follow the play that your team is committed to, then even  if it's a bad play, it will at least succeed 50% of the time which is far better than the 100% chance of failure from the previous situation.
I really appreciate that quote, it's very logical and something I never considered.

> [{quoted}](name=Fuh Queue,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IQOWsyXX,comment-id=00010001,timestamp=2017-03-10T14:35:02.353+0000)
>
> I really appreciate that quote, it's very logical and something I never considered.

It can be painful to put into practice sometimes though. lol

> [{quoted}](name=Bandle City,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IQOWsyXX,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2017-03-10T13:56:22.636+0000)
> "In Solo Queue it's better to make the play that your team is committed to than the one that seems the smartest." 

Except that my team didn't want to "make plays." They had the mentality of "we dominated early game, so in comes the easy win." I would _wait_ to see my teammates' positions before I did _anything_ to the other team. For example: my team was in a great position to start a fight 4 v 3. I tried getting closer to initiate it, but my team just sat back doing nothing. The other team then rallied together and aced us. My team was playing reactively; they weren't about "making plays."

>This is because in your typical game of League, not everyone thinks a like and not everyone knows how to play the strategy game. If you're the only one that is thinking about making a specific play but you know you can't do it alone or that you aren't the right member of the team to make that play then it will fail 100% of the time even if it's the best possible play to make. 

By that logic, I am doomed to fail 100 percent of the time; I literally cannot leave bronze if I agree with you. You are saying that I need to play reactively as well, waiting for an opportunity that either won't come, or won't be capitalized on. I can't make plays; you are telling me carrying isn't a real concept, and that if I win, it's because I was lucky enough for my team to all be on the same page.

>If you follow the play that your team is committed to, then even if it's a bad play, it will at least succeed 50% of the time which is far better than the 100% chance of failure from the previous situation.

So wait, you're telling me I have to wait for all of my teammates to "magically" be on the same page, and that I have to "magically" understand what they are doing and follow it and we will win 50 percent of the time? That's fucking asinine. I'm supposed to rely on my teammates in order to win? Whatever happened to carrying games? What if the game is just like this one?

> [{quoted}](name=Lesbian Lopunny,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=IQOWsyXX,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2017-03-10T14:12:54.604+0000)
>
> Except that my team didn't want to "make plays." They had the mentality of "we dominated early game, so in comes the easy win." I would _wait_ to see my teammates' positions before I did _anything_ to the other team. For example: my team was in a great position to start a fight 4 v 3. I tried getting closer to initiate it, but my team just sat back doing nothing. The other team then rallied together and aced us. My team was playing reactively; they weren't about "making plays."
> 
> By that logic, I am doomed to fail 100 percent of the time; I literally cannot leave bronze if I agree with you. You are saying that I need to play reactively as well, waiting for an opportunity that either won't come, or won't be capitalized on. I can't make plays; you are telling me carrying isn't a real concept, and that if I win, it's because I was lucky enough for my team to all be on the same page.
> 
> So wait, you're telling me I have to wait for all of my teammates to "magically" be on the same page, and that I have to "magically" understand what they are doing and follow it and we will win 50 percent of the time? That's fucking asinine. I'm supposed to rely on my teammates in order to win? Whatever happened to carrying games? What if the game is just like this one?

You need to look at the advice I gave you more objectively than that. Each game of league is different, there will be games where this advice doesn't apply and other's where it does. Most of this advice was in regards to how you handled your team not using it's Baron buff by attempting to split pushing yourself. It's about knowing yours and your own teams limits. To solo carry, you need to have a keen eye for all of the plays that only require actions made by yourself to pull of, it's still a concept that can be done, but not as easily in season 7 as it was in the past.

Every game though, it's worth sizing up your allies as well as your opponents, try to get a grasp on their playstyles as quickly as you can and then as late game roles around, look to make plays using the information that you've gathered. Let's say that you're really good at flanking the enemy out of stealth in a team fight, that is all well and good, but if your team isn't in sync with your strategy or they don't know how to follow it up then it won't work. I wasn't saying that you're doomed 100% of the time or anything like that, not even close; I do apologize that that's how you read it though. It just takes a change of mindset. You need to look at the game from a different angle. 

Maybe this will be more helpful...

Without being toxic about it, think of your team mates like pawns in a game of chess. To you, they are just means to an end. Each pawn in this scenario though has different abilities, strengths, and weaknesses however. That said, always watch for ways to "USE" your team mates in the least risky way possible. Learn to manipulate them into doing something you want them to do without them even knowing that you're doing it. This is how I've started to play recently and it's really  helped me out a lot over my past few game.

***Bare in mind, I only recently adopted this strategy so the results of it are still shoddy at best, but at the very least, I feel more in control of my games now which is helping out in it's own right.***

>Let's say that you're really good at flanking the enemy out of stealth in a team fight, that is all well and good, but if your team isn't in sync with your strategy or they don't know how to follow it up then it won't work.

You're genuinely telling me to never do anything, then. I can't possibly know if my team will follow up. If I try and they don't, we lose. If I try and they do, it's ambiguous. I'm doomed to fail 100 percent of the time because I should make the logical assumption (for bronze) that my team will never follow up on anything I do. I can choose to engage, we can lose, and I can reinforce my helplessness. I'm _still_ fated by the actions of my team. It doesn't _matter_ what I do; I have to 'wait for my team and hope we will be better than the other team if we fight.' How am I supposed to get out of bronze with that mentality?

>Each pawn in this scenario though has different abilities, strengths, and weaknesses however.

I can't _know_ their strengths or weaknesses (as a player) because I've never played with them before! You're telling me to have faith in my teammates, but assume they are never going to help me or do anything that makes logical sense. That's inherently contradictory.

> Learn to manipulate them into doing something you want them to do without them even knowing that you're doing it.

That's incredibly vague. It seems more like you aren't changing how you play, you are just giving yourself the illusion of control by acting like your teammates are pawns; that doesn't sound helpful. I don't even know what you mean by 'getting someone else to do something you want without them even knowing you made them do it.' Sounds like something a motivational speaker would say, and I don't like motivational speakers.

I guess I'll just play around my team, then. I'm bound to whatever collective choice they make and fail or succeed, I can't do anything about it but play the game in my role, so to speak. I won't split push even when no one else will do it, I won't initiate if I am not an initiator even if someone else won't do it, and if I am an initiator, I will just 1 v 5 the enemy team. Even though that sounds like inting, at least I'm playing to my role, right?

> I decide to do it, I get collapsed on, die

You are a squishy glass cannon who excels at shredding through teams, and you decided to split, because you have baron and for no other reason. They have two globals and a WW ult. Really not sure how you thought there would be any other outcome.

Just because your Irelia made a dumb decision doesn't mean you should follow suit.

You're wrong. I split because we had baron and no one else would split push. She made the decision to never split push, even though we had baron and a massive opportunity for gaining map control. Was I supposed to just sit mid and wait for baron to run out, hoping Irelia will split a lane?

You could just ask her.

Even if she refused, that doesn't mean you, as a glass cannon, and possibly the least qualified person on your team to split push (except for the support), should run off on your own when the enemy team is missing. That is just asking for them to jump on you.

Well first I'd have to say SPLITPUSHING IS OPTIONAL as is (believe it or not) BARON. While Irelia is an excellent split pusher she is also extremely handy in team fights due to her E and R, Tf is an excellent counter to that entire strategy and as a Twitch who can't STEALTH AWAY because of TF ult, you gave a free kill to the most dangerous enemy on that team. Just cause you have baron doesn't mean spliting the length of it, 2 baroned siege minions will easily take from longer range than the turret, so cover them (winions exists for a reason).

 That near perfect fight in MID game was a HUGE help to them, gold, objectives and morale. And as an ADC or APC i will say only this, Patience will bring down the tallest of trees (opening will appear). BUT THE BIGGEST PROBLEM WAS THE LACK OF LETHALITY against a team that built more armor than health which meant those 3 BOTRKs were useless, they counter built your team . By the end of the game Yorick was basically unkillabe which let Ashe keep you in range of her fed TF. But this is all from match history so, salt.
Not good to split against TF. They had a solid front line and your team had little CC. Needed a pick or an over engage from them.

You lost all momentum you may have had at the ~23 minute mark presumably due to a bad call on your team's part, when they got an almost clean ace (losing only WW) and were able to get 3 towers and an inhib off of that. I'm guessing the quadrakill your team got right after that was from them staying in your base for too long, and since they were so far pushed up you were only able to get one tower while WW was up. 

At this point they were up 2 towers and an inhib on you (both teams had previously taken 2 towers) and completely decimated your gold lead. The only reason you guys hanged in there another 20 minutes is because it seemed like your team was performing well and generally equally matched. But after that failed skirmish at the 23 min mark they were on completely equal ground with you and it was anybody's game. 

Without actually watching the game it is hard to say what you could have done differently. This is one of those cases were it was two well matched teams. They just were able to make the right plays at the right time, whether that is luck, from coordination on their part, or from mistakes on your teams part it is hard to say. Sometimes you couldn't have done anything differently, it is what it is. 

It didn't help, btw, that your team was basically all AD (with Morgana going more of a support build and less AP) and none of you bought penetration. That made Ali's, Yorick's, and WW's jobs (tank) much easier and meant winning your late game was always going to be rough.

You're entire response could be summated by: c'est la vie. 

Apparently, I'm hopeless to forces out of my control and if I win, it's _explicitly_ because I was lucky. So I guess I can assume that I'm only going to be in bronze because I'm unlucky, right? There is just nothing I can do, right? Challenger players don't win because of coordination; no, they win because of luck.

I'm not trying to sound like a dick, but that's essentially what you just said.

No, I explained why you lost. 

Without looking at a replay we _can't_ tell you what calls you should/shouldn't have made, and what you should do to improve. We, for example, looking at the match history have no clue how they were able to get 5 kills for 1 and 3 towers/1 inhib at the 23min mark. We just know that it happened, and it was a big factor in their eventual win. But I can't tell you what you should have done instead because I don't know what you actually _did_.

All we can do is look at the straight statistics, and tell you how why they were able to win based off the objective information given to us alone.

What I can tell you is they had 3 people stacking armor, 2 with ninja tabis that make your aa's do 12% less damage to them, and one giving one of the carries 20 armor (knight's vow). Your 3 main damage dealers, _who all do primarily ad damage via autoattacks_,  including yourself did not buy any last whisper items, and the only penetration you guys bought was Lucians' yomous for 15 lethality which is a joke against late game tanks. That IS one of the reasons you guys lost. You guys needed better builds.

There's no blanket statement like: "get more wards on the map," or: "don't split up from one another" that you could tell me?

I don't understand how I'm supposed to improve if I'm apparently supposed to do whatever my team collectively does, regardless of how stupid it is, and not try anything. This game was a testament of "trying something" being a hollow concept. Clearly, there is a definitive way of playing this game that could be written on paper that I haven't been told; this game does not encourage lateral thinking whatsoever.

So improving isn't something that exists. If I am helpless to whatever my teammates decide to do, I can't do anything but what they do. Meaning if they want to lose, I have to be brought down with them. Furthermore, this supports me never getting out of bronze.

I don't agree with this logic, but I'm seeing that it may be more truthful that I had hoped. I would like it if lateral thinking and individual skill meant something, but it doesn't seem to.

Without seeing where you guys were warding, when you guys were splitting up, etc and what the other team was doing blanket statements are not much help.

Things like ward more, stick together, etc only help so much. Eventually it is less about warding more and more about warding _smartly _ (because everyone "wards more" in higher elos for example), better map awareness, recognizing enemy behavior patterns (have they been playing cautiously but suddenly are very aggressive despite low health and/or mana? You are probably be baited into a gank. Are you guys about to gank but the normally aggressive enemy is suddenly cautious? He probably knows about the gank which means your ganker is probably sitting next to or walked by a ward), and recognizing when fights are lost causes and abandoning teammates to die, recognizing when teammates are sacrificing themselves to save you/your objectives etc. Those are more nuance though, and it is harder to give you the advice you need without actually seeing you play.
I must have the mentality of someone higher than bronze, then, considering everything you just said is obvious to me.

One mistake late is game over
Also your team doesn't look great compared to theirs late game in team fights

The "mistake" wasn't late, it was early on. It just got progressively worse to the point where we literally couldn't push out a lane without either getting into a losing teamfight, or someone getting picked off.

That was their team comp , split pushing as twitch doesn't make sense 

No one on your team had  {{item:3035}}  , you can't hope to deal with 3 tanks like that , also no one had  {{item:3123}}   for ww

And basically you were full ad with ap supp you can't hope to win that shit late game without armor pen

It's actually surprising you dragged the game along for so long

>That was their team comp , split pushing as twitch doesn't make sense 

If I can't do it, and no one else will, we lose; you realize the problem there, right?

>No one on your team had {{item:3035}}, you can't hope to deal with 3 tanks like that , also no one had {{item:3123}}  for ww

Our problems extended beyond killing them. Our micro was passable for the early game, but it got worse as the game went on. The macro was our issue for the entire game.

>It's actually surprising you dragged the game along for so long

Probably because our micro wasn't terrible and we got early dragons. We had some, albeit lucky, engages and picks. We had a pick comp, and I was the only one on my team to realize it and play to it. If I had to guess, that's why it lasted as long as it did.
So you saying you lost coz your team was bad , ok ......................
More specifically, I said _our_ macro was bad. Don't say something that can easily be taken out of context.

Then you turtle or move as a group until the enemy team makes a mistake, place wards where you can(not alone)


Then if an enemy is alone, catch him out. proceed to use advantage in a timely manner.


And if one person won't listen, the team can just follow that person.


Stubbornness doesn't counter stubbornness mate.

I'm jungling, I don't have a sightstone. I can only place so many wards.

>Then if an enemy is alone, catch him out. proceed to use advantage in a timely manner.

That happened at least once because I initiated it. That doesn't matter when you don't have good macro. Also, it could have happened more, but my team refused to jump at the opportunity of any mis-positioning.

>And if one person won't listen, the team can just follow that person.

That leads to more defeats than victories, you know. It's why my last account's win rate for ranked was less than 40 percent.

Then you either play around the opposite side of the map of the other since he wont listen. 


The bad macro is you and your teams fault period.


If team wont listen then you sit back and wait for your team to do something, otherwise go to next game and hope you don't get them on your team.



And no it doesn't well, maybe in lower elos where everyone would rather castrate each other than find a way to win.
the enemy team sucked less than your team and you lost.
I'm already tired of the pointless responses. Why bother coming here if you aren't going to say anything useful?
it's the truth tho. for everysingle league game
That still begs the question of why they were better, or in what ways they were better.

doesnt matter it's league roll with it. same way the enemy who has 3 games on Naut can win a 60% winrate rengar main with 100games in diamond 2. makes sence? no i roll with it. cant do anything else anyway.
